p.s: In his speech for the opening ceremony of the climate conference COP26, prime minister Boris Johnson appeals directly to the assembled world leaders, stressing the urgency and the consequences that will follow if the conference fails at reaching an agreement on how to fight climate change.

He puts pressure on them, by empasizingempathizing the consequences for the future, the importance of the conference for the course and outcome of history and the fact, that the world's population is watching and relying on them.
In order to achieve his effect on the assembled audience, he begins his speech by stressingn the immediate danger of climate cahnge and therefore the urgency to act against it.
Thus, he compares the situation of the leaders to the fictional, well-known character James Bond (ll. 2-9).
By doing so, he illustrates just hwo dangerous climate change is: that it will will end human life as we know it (l. 5).
The raise of global temperature is compared to a doomsday device and the global leaders are metaphorically strapedstrapped to this device, meanwhile a red digital clock is ticking.
This shows how life-threatheninglife-threatening and immedaite the menace of global warming is.
The negatively connotated alliteration doomsday device represents the possible outcome of this scenario.
It refers to an apocalyptic future, a doomsday that will come, if the conference fails.
The negativly connotated word tragedy (l. 6) also adds to that effect.
For James Bond movies usually have a happy neding, there is also a future scenario in which the earth will be saved and the conference a success.
Johnson continues in putting pressure on the assembled politicians, by mentioning past climate summits in the following paragraph (ll. 10-15).
He states, that the promise made back then, will be nothing but blah, blah, blah if the COP26 fails (ll. 12f).
By resorting to a more informal language, Johnson uses humorism to again stress the importance of action against climate change.
By doing so, he also appeals to the audience watching, that will be according to him full of anger (l. 13) and impatience (l. 13) if the conference fails.
The familiar term get real also appeals to a younger, impatient audience (l. 14).
In a further paragraph, he presents the means by which it is possible to stop global warming.

By ennumerating the means that may stop climate change, he puts emphasis on the fact that We have the technology (l. 30) to do something against climate change, but that there is a lack of will to implement this technology.
In order to pressure the politicians even more to implement this technology, to find the will to do so, he refers to the crowds of young people outside.
Furthermore, he draws a parallel between the conclave and the assembled leaders at the conference (l. 35).
By doing so, he emphasizes the age difference between the politicians and the young people, whose future is affected.
The conclave and the pope usually tend to be very old and they play a very important role in for the catholicCatholic church.
By comparing the conclave and the members of the conference, Johnson also elevates their role as decision makers as well as their age.
In the next paragraph, Johnson puts the age difference, between the members of COP26 and the younger generations, into context.
He states, that the yet unborn children will judge the members of COP26 with bitterness and resentment (l. 41).
It shows, that the people who are beeingbeing affected by this crisis are yet not even born.
The members of COP26 will therefore be dead by then.
Henceforth, Johnson illustrates the responsiblities taht the leaders hold.
They will be responsible and judged for in the future.
Even if they are dead by the year 2060 (l. 36), their actions today will have ana direct and heavy impact on the lives of future generations.
The COP26 conference is therefore a historic turning point.
This metaphoremetaphor stresses the importance of the COP26 conference, so important that it can change the course of history and will go down in it.
In the end of his speech, Johnson refers back to his analogy of James Bond, by saying we may not feel like James Bond (l. 47) and defuse the bomb (l. 49).
Thus he reminds the COP26 members agin of their position as decision makers facing a great threat bomb.
He ends his speech with the words But yes, we can do it (l. 51), spreading optimism and hope.
All in all, Johnson tries to appeal foremost to his audicen, the assembled leaders in the room, in order to pressure them to take action against climate cahnge.
He does so, using inclusive language, like we, putting pressure on them, while also assuring them that there is also reason for hope.
